alt_statements.statement: As someone who runs his own small business and has a disability, I see AI as a tool that can open doors—making work safer, more efficient, and more accessible, especially in fields like medical equipment where lives are on the line. But powerful tools need strong rules: we need clear, enforceable regulations to prevent discrimination, protect people’s jobs and privacy, and make sure AI benefits working families and not just big corporations. Any AI that touches health, safety, or our communities should be transparent, tested like medical devices, and guided by diverse voices—including Native communities—so it doesn’t repeat the injustices we already live with.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a practical tool to make work more efficient, improve manufacturing, and help with things like healthcare and public safety, not to replace people or undermine human dignity. It needs strict regulations, clear accountability, and strong oversight so that big companies and governments can’t misuse it, especially against ordinary workers and families. Any AI decisions that affect people’s lives—jobs, finances, legal matters—should always be reviewable by a real person with moral responsibility. Above all, AI must respect human life, privacy, and traditional values, serving people rather than controlling them.

As someone who works with physical materials and sees how small design choices affect real structures, I think AI should be a powerful tool that helps us solve concrete problems—like cutting waste, improving safety, and making everyday life more sustainable—without replacing human judgment or creativity. It ought to be developed and used in a way that’s transparent, accountable, and democratically regulated, with strong protections against bias, surveillance, and corporate abuse.

As someone who works in a library and sees every day how information shapes people’s lives, I think artificial intelligence should be a helpful tool that makes our work and daily tasks easier, not something that replaces human judgment, relationships, or responsibility. I believe we need clear, enforceable rules—set by a mix of government, independent experts, and everyday citizens—that require transparency about how AI systems work, protect people’s privacy and jobs, and prevent bias or misuse.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly as a tool to make life easier and work more efficient, but not as a replacement for human judgment or responsibility. It ought to be transparent and tested carefully, especially when it affects people’s jobs, privacy, or access to services. Rules and oversight should come from a mix of government, independent experts, and the public, so no one group has too much control. Overall, I’d like to see steady, practical progress with clear safeguards rather than rushing ahead and cleaning up the mess later.

As someone who spent her life caring for patients, I think artificial intelligence should be used to support people, not replace them—especially in areas like healthcare, where compassion and human judgment matter. Artificial intelligence should serve as a tool to assist human judgment, not replace it, particularly in areas like medicine, defense, and education where moral responsibility must remain firmly in human hands. We need strict, transparent regulations and strong oversight—ideally by elected officials accountable to the public—to prevent abuses by corporations and governments, protect privacy, and uphold our moral and religious values.

As someone who spent her life in education and community work, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that should serve people—especially the most vulnerable—by improving access to learning, healthcare, and social services, not by replacing human care or judgment. But given how easily it can deepen inequality or spread harm, I believe AI must be tightly regulated through transparent laws, strong public oversight, and firm ethical standards grounded in human dignity, fairness, and the common good.

As someone who works in architectural design, I see AI as a powerful tool to boost creativity, improve safety, and cut down on tedious work—but not as a replacement for human judgment, ethics, or empathy. I think we need strong, enforceable regulations that prioritize transparency, worker protections, and bias reduction, especially for systems that impact jobs, housing, healthcare, and policing. AI development should be overseen by independent public agencies, not just tech companies, and include input from everyday people, not only experts and executives.

As someone who cares for people in their homes every day, I see AI as a tool that should support human dignity, not replace human connection or jobs, especially for workers like caregivers who are often underpaid and overlooked. AI can help with scheduling, translation, and health monitoring, but decisions that affect people’s lives and livelihoods must remain in human hands, with strong regulations to prevent bias, discrimination, and corporate abuse. Communities—especially immigrants, low-income families, and front-line workers—should have a say in how AI is used and governed, not just tech companies and politicians.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a tool to make life more efficient and improve services like healthcare, public safety, and national defense, but it must never replace human judgment or responsibility. We need strong, common-sense regulations that protect privacy, prevent abuse by big corporations or foreign adversaries, and keep Americans in control of how these systems are used. AI should reflect our country’s moral and Christian values, not undermine them, and it should be developed in ways that support work and community, not tear them apart.

I think AI should be used to make everyday life smoother and fairer for people, like improving healthcare, public services, and education—not just to boost profits for big companies. But we need strong rules, like government oversight and clear accountability, to make sure it doesn’t take people’s jobs without a safety net, invade privacy, or build in bias against certain groups. AI should support workers, not replace them, and decisions that really affect people’s lives should always have a human being responsible at the end of the line.

As someone who works in construction sales and sees how technology can make jobs safer and more efficient, I think AI should be used to take over the most dangerous, repetitive tasks while helping people do higher-skill, better-paid work. But we can’t just trust companies to police themselves—AI needs strong, transparent regulations, worker protections, and civil rights safeguards, with input from everyday people, not just tech executives. As a liberal and a Jew, I’m especially concerned about bias, surveillance, and inequality, so I believe AI systems should be audited for fairness and kept accountable to democratic institutions.

I think artificial intelligence should be used mainly to make everyday life easier and more efficient—things like improving healthcare, transportation, and education—without replacing the human touch that people need, especially children and the elderly. It worries me that it could cost people their jobs or be used to spread lies, so I believe we need strict, common-sense rules, clear oversight, and real human accountability to keep it in its place.

I think robots and computers that can think, like AI, should help people be safe, healthy, and happy, like helping doctors, teachers, and even kids who need extra help learning. But grown-ups should make strong rules so the AI can’t be used to hurt people, be mean or unfair, or spy on us all the time. I believe God wants us to use our inventions to care for others, so we should always check that AI is being honest, kind, and used to help everyone, not just a few people.

As someone who cares a lot about my community and the future my little siblings are growing up into, I think AI should be used to make life fairer and easier for regular people—like improving education, healthcare, and access to jobs—not just boosting profits for big companies. But because I’ve seen how bias and discrimination already show up in our systems, I believe AI has to be tightly regulated with strong civil rights protections, transparency about how it works, and real accountability when it harms people, especially Black and low-income communities.

I see artificial intelligence as a useful tool that can make essential services like energy, healthcare, and public safety more reliable and efficient, but it shouldn’t replace human judgment or responsibility. We need clear, enforceable regulations—preferably at the national level—that require transparency, human oversight in high‑risk decisions, and strong protections for privacy and jobs. I’d like to see everyday citizens, not just tech companies and politicians, have a seat at the table when AI policies are made.

As a business owner, a mom, and someone who cares a lot about health and wellness, I see AI as a powerful tool that should make our lives easier, safer, and fairer—whether that’s in healthcare, education, or how we run companies. But we can’t just “move fast and break things” with something this powerful: we need strong, enforceable regulations, transparency about how systems work, and real accountability when AI harms people or deepens inequalities. I want my kids to grow up in a world where AI expands opportunity and respects everyone’s rights and dignity, not one where profits or convenience come before human well‑being.

At my age, I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that ought to serve human dignity, expand access to education and healthcare, and reduce drudgery—much as earlier technologies did when wisely governed. But history teaches that concentrated power and unregulated innovation invite abuse, so we need strong democratic oversight, transparency requirements, and public, not just corporate, control over how AI is developed and deployed. AI systems that affect people’s rights, livelihoods, or safety should be subject to rigorous testing, independent auditing, and clear avenues for redress, just as we do with drugs or financial instruments. In short, we should welcome AI’s benefits, but insist that its risks be managed through accountable public institutions rather than left to the market’s good intentions.

As someone who works directly with vulnerable families, I see huge potential for AI to help us spot needs earlier, reduce paperwork, and free up more time for real human connection and care. But because the people I serve can’t afford to be “test cases,” AI in society should be tightly governed with strong privacy protections, transparency about how decisions are made, and clear accountability when things go wrong. I’d like to see diverse communities, including immigrants and frontline workers like me, genuinely involved in setting the rules so AI tools support human dignity instead of undermining it.

I think artificial intelligence can be a helpful tool, especially if it makes everyday things like healthcare, education, and customer service cheaper and easier for regular families like mine. But it shouldn’t be running the show or replacing people’s jobs, and it has to respect our privacy, our faith, and our basic freedoms. I’d want strong, common-sense rules from our elected leaders to keep big tech and the government from misusing AI, while still allowing honest businesses to use it in ways that actually help folks.

I think robots and smart computers should help people do hard or dangerous jobs, like fixing big machines or helping doctors, so people have more time to learn, play, and be with family. But there should be kind and wise grown-ups, from many countries and religions, making rules so AI can’t hurt people, be unfair to anyone, or spy on us too much. My parents and teachers should be able to understand how it works so they can teach me to use it safely and in a way that pleases Allah.

Artificial intelligence ought to be used as a tool to make our systems safer and more efficient—whether that’s keeping the lights on, improving infrastructure, or helping communities use energy more responsibly—without replacing the judgment and responsibility of real people. We need strong, enforceable safety standards, clear accountability when something goes wrong, and public oversight so that AI doesn’t concentrate power in the hands of a few corporations or government agencies.

Artificial intelligence should be used as a practical tool to make work and daily life more efficient, not as a replacement for human judgment, responsibility, or compassion. I’d like to see clear, enforceable regulations—similar to workplace safety or financial rules—that require transparency, protect people’s jobs and privacy, and make sure someone is always accountable when things go wrong. At the same time, we shouldn’t fear every new development; if we involve a broad range of voices, including workers and ordinary citizens, we can steer AI toward serving the common good rather than just a few powerful interests.

I see artificial intelligence as a powerful tool that, if guided well, can free people up to focus more on creativity, care, and community—kind of like how a good set of tools transforms a workshop. But it has to be governed with strong public oversight, transparency, and regulations that put ordinary people, workers, and civil rights first, not just corporate profit. We ought to treat AI like critical infrastructure: democratically controlled, audited for bias and safety, and shaped to reduce inequality rather than deepen it.
